additional_comments: If new tech is an object of interest, that is one thing, but when 'new' tends toward obsession, it is misguided. I remember when I was first starting in actuarial science, and having had a physics baccalaureate, when studying for exam P I investigated quantum probability models. I also remember attending seminars a few years ago when interest in InsureTech peaked. So I get the excitement. But what excites isn't necessarily what gets the work done. Take Power BI. Some departments in our company are trying to force ways to use Power BI now because it's trendy, even though there is little room for it in their workflow and it actually reduces productivity due to that.     Avant-garde tech and tried-and-true tech aren't equivalent. For actuarial purposes, one requires some tool to import and/or process data. Then one needs tools to manipulate it, and then something to present it. To a surprisingly broad extent of my business's purposes, Excel seems to work just fine still - at least in the manipulation department. I realize that it's 1990s tech, but it's a lingua franca of sorts throughout the field because of its enduring presence. Sure, you can't look cool to your peers if you're an Excel whiz anymore, but actuarial science isn't cool and isn't supposed to be.     In sum tools that can churn data and push it into formats that Excel can work with are valuable, and they keep the industry standardized.
